title: Survivors of the Santa Cruz boat fire jumped ship and paddled to another vessel, banging on its hull until the owners woke up
text:
Santa Barbara County Fire Department via AP





Survivors from the Santa Cruz boat fire on Monday paddled a dinghy to a nearby yacht and hammered its hull until the owners woke up.

Shirley and Bob Hansen told the LA Times they helped several people out of the water onto their 18-meter fishing boat, the Grape Escape, at 3:30 a.m.

The Conception, a scuba diving boat, caught fire at around 3:00 a.m. local time. Rescuers confirmed on Tuesday that 25 people lost their lives.

20 bodies have been recovered by rescue crews, and another five located. Nine people remain missing.

Shirley Hansen said some of those she brought onboard were only wearing their underwear, and that two crew members went back to look for other survivors.

A group of survivors from the Santa Cruz boat fire which took the lives of at least 25 people paddled a rescue dinghy to a nearby ship and pounded the hull until the owners woke up.

Shirley and Bob Hansen told the LA Times they woke to loud banging on the hull of their 59-foot fishing boat, the Grape Escape, at 3:30 a.m. on Monday.

After coming above deck, the couple told the LA Times they saw the Conception, a 75-foot scuba diving boat on a Labor Day trip for 39 people, on fire nearby, while survivors clambered aboard.

The survivors, all crew members, were given blankets and sweaters, as some were only wearing their underwear, Shirley Hansen told the Times.

One of the survivors suffered a broken leg, according to a report from local news station ABC News 7.

She added that the smoke billowing from the wreckage was so thick she was forced to use her inhaler, despite her vessel's distance from the fire.

Hansen said two of the survivors recused were part of the Conception's six-man crew, and paddled back to the boat to look for survivors, but failed to find anyone.

"They came back and there was no one that they found," Hansen told the LA Times.

The boat caught fire near Santa Cruz Island, off the coast of Ventura County, California, just after 3:00 a.m. local time on Monday morning. Coast guards overheard a mayday call that the boat was on fire at around 3:15 a.m, the LA Times said.

ABC 7 reported that the boat was chartered for a weekend dive trip which started on August 31, and was scheduled to end Tuesday.

The bodies of 25 people have been located and 20 recovered so far, Coast Guard Lt. Cmdr Matthew Kroll told the Associated Press. Nine others — one crew member and eight passengers — remain missing.

Investigators have not yet determined what caused the ship to catch fire.
description: The Conception, a scuba diving boat, burst into flame just after 3:00 a.m. on Monday. Rescuers confirmed on Tuesday that 25 people lost their lives.
